title: WA seeks nominations for TAB privatisation
text:
The state also said WA TAB has recorded about $340 million revenue a year for the past three years and was said to have 45,000 "active core" customer accounts and "low average ticket value with opportunity to grow customer spend".

WA TAB was pitched as the last of the once-state-run totalisers to be privatised, with an opportunity to operational efficiencies through enhanced scale and incremental revenues by leveraging "private sector capital and expertise".

The new licensee will be able to roll out simulated racing inside TAB agencies - a la Tabcorp's Trackside - and focus on fixed odds betting, which is an underpenetrated market in WA compared to other states.

ASX-listed Tabcorp, which holds similar long-term licences in Victoria, NSW, Queensland, South Australia, Tasmania, Northern Territory and the ACT, shapes as the most logical acquirer. It has both the track record and the most available synergies given its existing footprint. Investment bank UBS is tending to Tabcorp.

WA and its advisers will be seeking to draw in offshore-owned corporate bookmakers into the auction, including Sportsbet, BetEasy and Ladbrokes. Sportsbet and Ladbrokes have experience operating betting shops in their home markets, and each is expected to at least take a look at the WA opportunity.

Interested parties were asked to formally express their interest in WA TAB and expect formal sale documents in November. WA is targeting a signed deal in mid-2020.
description: Western Australia is finally seeking starters for its long talked about wagering privatisation.
